data.text:
Convert the following grammar to Chomsky Normal Form (as described in the lecture video):

X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z

W $$\rightarrow$$ Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ e

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X W Z

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y @X_Y
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@X_Y $$\rightarrow$$ Z W

W $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_X
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@W_X $$\rightarrow$$ W Z

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X @Z_X
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@Z_X $$\rightarrow$$ W Z
--------------------

--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y @X_Y
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@X_Y $$\rightarrow$$ Z W

W $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_X
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ e
W $$\rightarrow$$ Z
@W_X $$\rightarrow$$ W Z

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X @Z_X
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@Z_X $$\rightarrow$$ W Z
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove all empty rules and unary rules after collapsing them.

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y @Z_W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@Z_W $$\rightarrow$$ Z W

W $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@W_Z $$\rightarrow$$ W Z

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_Z
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ @X_W W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@X_W $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z

W $$\rightarrow$$ @W_Z Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@W_Z $$\rightarrow$$ X W

Z $$\rightarrow$$ @Z_Z Z
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@Z_Z $$\rightarrow$$ X W
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y @Z_W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@Z_W $$\rightarrow$$ Z W

W $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ e
@W_Z $$\rightarrow$$ W Z

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X @W_Z
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ @X_W W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z
@X_W $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z

W $$\rightarrow$$ @W_Z Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ e
@W_Z $$\rightarrow$$ X W

Z $$\rightarrow$$ @Z_Z Z
Z $$\rightarrow$$ X Z
@Z_Z $$\rightarrow$$ X W
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y @X_Y
@X_Y $$\rightarrow$$ Z W
X $$\rightarrow$$ Y Z

W $$\rightarrow$$ Z
W $$\rightarrow$$ e

Z $$\rightarrow$$ X @Z_X
@Z_X $$\rightarrow$$ W Z
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove all empty and unary rules.

data.text:
Convert the following grammar to Chomsky Normal Form (as described in the lecture video):

A $$\rightarrow$$ B C

B $$\rightarrow$$ e
B $$\rightarrow$$ C C

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ C D D

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ C @A_C
@A_C $$\rightarrow$$ D D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ C @C_C
@C_C $$\rightarrow$$ D D
-------------------

--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ C @A_C
@A_C $$\rightarrow$$ D D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C
B $$\rightarrow$$ e

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ C @C_C
@C_C $$\rightarrow$$ D D
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove all empty rules and unary rules after collapsing them.

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ C @D_D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ C @D_D

@D_D $$\rightarrow$$ D D
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ @A_D D
@A_D $$\rightarrow$$ C D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ @C_D D
@C_D $$\rightarrow$$ C D
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ C @D_D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C
B $$\rightarrow$$e

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ C @D_D

@D_D $$\rightarrow$$ D D
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C
A $$\rightarrow$$ C D
A $$\rightarrow$$ @A_D D
@A_D $$\rightarrow$$ C D

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C
B $$\rightarrow$$ e

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ @C_D D
@C_D $$\rightarrow$$ C D
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
A $$\rightarrow$$ B C

B $$\rightarrow$$ C C

C $$\rightarrow$$ C D
C $$\rightarrow$$ @C_C C
@C_C $$\rightarrow$$ D D
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove (an collapse) all empty and unary rules.

data.text:
Convert the following grammar to Chomsky Normal Form (as described in the lecture video):

M $$\rightarrow$$ N R

N $$\rightarrow$$ P N R
N $$\rightarrow$$ e

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ P @N_P
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
@N_P $$\rightarrow$$ N R

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------

--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ P @N_P
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
N $$\rightarrow$$ e
@N_P $$\rightarrow$$ N R

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove all empty rules and unary rules after collapsing them.

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ P @N_R
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
@N_R $$\rightarrow$$ N R

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ @N_R R
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
@N_R $$\rightarrow$$ P N

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect.

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ P @N_R
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
N $$\rightarrow$$ e
@N_R $$\rightarrow$$ N R

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Your labeling of non-terminals created by binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R
M $$\rightarrow$$ P P

N $$\rightarrow$$ @N_R R
N $$\rightarrow$$ P R
N $$\rightarrow$$ e
@N_R $$\rightarrow$$ P N

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Your method of binarization is incorrect, and don't forget to remove all unary and empty rules.

option.text:
--------------------
M $$\rightarrow$$ N R

N $$\rightarrow$$ P @N_P
N $$\rightarrow$$ e
@N_P $$\rightarrow$$ N R

R $$\rightarrow$$ P P
--------------------
option.explanation: Don't forget to remove all empty and unary rules.

question_group.preamble:
Given the following grammar and transition probabilities:

S $$\rightarrow$$ NP VP0.9
S $$\rightarrow$$ VP0.1
VP $$\rightarrow$$ V NP0.5
VP $$\rightarrow$$ V0.1
VP $$\rightarrow$$ V @VP_V0.3
VP $$\rightarrow$$ V PP0.1
@VP_V $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP1.0
NP $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP0.1
NP $$\rightarrow$$ NP PP0.2
NP $$\rightarrow$$ N0.7
PP $$\rightarrow$$ P NP1.0

data.text:
And given the following part of the CKY matrix:



Which of the following constituents (and with what maximum probability) will be in the next cell?

option.explanation:
PP $$\rightarrow$$ P NP:
$$1.0 \times 0.1 \times 0.42 = 0.042$$.

VP $$\rightarrow$$ V followed by S $$\rightarrow$$ NP VP:
$$0.9 \times 0.2 \times (0.1 \times 0.4) = 0.0072$$

NP $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP:
$$0.1 \times 0.2 \times 0.42 = 0.0084$$

@VP_V $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP:
$$1.0 \times 0.2 \times 0.42 = 0.084$$
There is actually a higher probability way to get PP.

There is actually no way to get a VP in the next cell from what is given. You may have tried to apply the unary rule VP $$\rightarrow$$ V in the lower right cell, but that does not apply to the next cell.

You may have tried to apply the S $$\rightarrow$$ VP unary rule to the upper left cell, but that rule applies only to that cell - the S label does not go into the upper right cell (the cell we are concerned about).
You may have tried to apply the NP $$\rightarrow$$ N unary rule to the lower right cell, but that rule applies only to that cell, not to the cell we are concerned with (the upper right cell).

data.text:
And given the following part of the CKY matrix:



Which of the following constituents (and with what maximum probability) will be in the next cell?

option.explanation:
VP $$\rightarrow$$ V NP:
$$0.5 \times 0.2 \times 0.5 = 0.05$$

NP $$\rightarrow$$ NP PP:
$$0.2 \times 0.3 \times 0.3 = 0.018$$

PP $$\rightarrow$$ P NP:
$$1.0 \times 0.1 \times 0.5 = 0.05$$

@VP_V $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP:
$$1.0 \times 0.3 \times 0.5 = 0.15$$

Highest probability VP (VP $$\rightarrow$$ V NP) followed by S $$\rightarrow$$ VP:
$$(0.5 \times 0.2 \times 0.5) \times 0.1 = 0.005$$
$$0.1 \times 0.3 \times 0.5 = 0.015$$ (from the rule NP $$\rightarrow$$ NP NP) is not the highest probability way to form a NP in the next cell.
$$0.3 \times 0.2 \times 0.4 = 0.024$$ (from the rule VP $$\rightarrow$$ V @VP_V) is not the highest probability way to form a VP in the next cell.

You may have thought the rule S $$\rightarrow$$ NP VP applies using @VP_V instead of a VP ($$0.9 \times 0.3 \times 0.4 = 0.108$$). However, that would require the rule S $$\rightarrow$$ NP @VP_V, which does not exist.

data.text:
Given the following true and guessed parses, what is the LP/LR F1 (excluding any contribution from ROOT)?

Guess:
(ROOT
  (S
    (NP (DT The) (NN cDNA))
    (VP (VBZ has)
      (NP
        (NP (DT an) (JJ open) (NN reading) (NN frame))
        (PP (IN of)
          (NP
            (NP (JJ 900) (NN amino) (NNS acids))
            (ADJP (JJ capable)
              (PP (IN of)
                (S
                  (VP (VBG encoding)
                    (NP (DT a) (JJ 97-kDa) (NN protein))))))))))
    (. .)))

Gold:
(ROOT
  (S
    (NP (DT The) (NN cDNA))
    (VP (VBZ has)
      (NP
        (NP (DT an) (JJ open) (NN reading) (NN frame))
        (PP (IN of)
          (NP (CD 900) (NN amino) (NNS acids)))
        (ADJP (JJ capable)
          (PP (IN of)
            (S
              (VP (VBG encoding)
                (NP (DT a) (JJ 97-kDa) (NN protein))))))))
    (. .)))
data.explanation: With a labeled precision of $$0.8462$$ and recall of $$0.9167$$, we have a F1 of $$0.88$$.

option.explanation: With a precision of $$0.8462$$ and recall of $$0.9167$$, we have a F1 of $$0.88$$.
Don't include the terminal labels in your calculations.

F1 is not the average of precision and recall. It is given by
$$F = \frac{2}{1/P + 1/R} = \frac{2PR}{P+R}$$
This is the precision. We want F1.
This is the recall. We want F1.

data.text:
Lexicalize the following parse tree (annotate each non-terminal with the head of the phrase over which it is a constituent):

(S
  (NP (NNP William)
  (VP (VBD gave)
    (NP (DT the) (NN gift)
    (PP (TO to) (PRP her))))
(. .))
data.explanation:
The basic rules for head words of constituents in a parse tree are:
  • The head of a noun phrase (NP) is the last noun in the phrase.
  • The head of a verb phrase (VP) is the verb.
  • The head of a sentence (S) is the head of the main verb phrase.
  • The head of a prepositional phrase (PP) is the preposition.

option.text:
(S-gave
  (NP-William (NNP William)
  (VP-gave (VBD gave)
    (NP-gift (DT the) (NN gift)
    (PP-to (TO to) (PRP her))))
(. .))

(S-gave
  (NP-William (NNP William)
  (VP-gave (VBD gave)
    (NP-gift (DT the) (NN gift)
    (PP-her (TO to) (PRP her))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a prepositional phrase is the preposition.
In particular, it should be PP-to, not PP-her.

option.text:
(S-gave
  (NP-William (NNP William)
  (VP-gave (VBD gave)
    (NP-the (DT the) (NN gift)
    (PP-to (TO to) (PRP her))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a noun phrase is last noun in it.
In particular, it should be NP-gift, not NP-the.

option.text:
(S-William
  (NP-William (NNP William)
  (VP-gave (VBD gave)
    (NP-gift (DT the) (NN gift)
    (PP-to (TO to) (PRP her))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a sentence is the head of the main verb phrase.
In particular, it should be S-gave, not S-William.

data.text:

(S
  (PP (TO to)
    (NP (PRP him)))
  (NP (PRP she))
  (VP (VBD was)
    (NP (DT a) (JJ good) (NN friend))))
(. .))
data.explanation:
The basic rules for head words of constituents in a parse tree are:
  • The head of a noun phrase (NP) is the last noun in the phrase.
  • The head of a verb phrase (VP) is the verb.
  • The head of a sentence (S) is the head of the main verb phrase.
  • The head of a prepositional phrase (PP) is the preposition.

option.text:
(S-was
  (PP-to (TO to)
    (NP-him (PRP him)))
  (NP-she (PRP she))
  (VP-was (VBD was)
    (NP-friend (DT a) (JJ good) (NN friend))))
(. .))

(S-she
  (PP-to (TO to)
    (NP-him (PRP him)))
  (NP-she (PRP she))
  (VP-was (VBD was)
    (NP-friend (DT a) (JJ good) (NN friend))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a sentence is the head of the main verb phrase.
In particular, it should be S-was, not S-she.

option.text:
(S-was
  (PP-him (TO to)
    (NP-him (PRP him)))
  (NP-she (PRP she))
  (VP-was (VBD was)
    (NP-friend (DT a) (JJ good) (NN friend))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a prepositional phrase is the preposition.
In particular, it should be PP-to, not PP-him.

option.text:
(S-to
  (PP-to (TO to)
    (NP-him (PRP him)))
  (NP-she (PRP she))
  (VP-was (VBD was)
    (NP-friend (DT a) (JJ good) (NN friend))))
(. .))
option.explanation:
The head of a sentence is the head of the main verb phrase.
In particular, it should be S-was, not S-to.

data.text:
Lexicalize the following parse tree (annotate each non-terminal with the head of the phrase over which it is a constituent):

(S
  (NP (PRP$ her) (NN husband))
  (VP (VBD cleared)
    (NP
      (NP (DT a) (NN visit))
      (PP
        (IN by)
        (NP (PRP$ her) (NN mother))))))
(. .)

option.text:
(S-cleared
  (NP-husband (PRP$ her) (NN husband))
  (VP-cleared (VBD cleared)
    (NP-visit
      (NP-visit (DT a) (NN visit))
      (PP-by
        (IN by)
        (NP-mother (PRP$ her) (NN mother))))))
(. .)

(S-husband
  (NP-husband (PRP$ her) (NN husband))
  (VP-cleared (VBD cleared)
    (NP-visit
      (NP-visit (DT a) (NN visit))
      (PP-by
        (IN by)
        (NP-mother (PRP$ her) (NN mother))))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head of a sentence is the head of the main verb phrase.
In particular, it should be S-cleared, not S-husband.

option.text:
(S-cleared
  (NP-her (PRP$ her) (NN husband))
  (VP-cleared (VBD cleared)
    (NP-visit
      (NP-visit (DT a) (NN visit))
      (PP-by
        (IN by)
        (NP-her (PRP$ her) (NN mother))))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head of a noun phrase is the main noun in the phrase.
In particular, it should be NP-husband and NP-mother, not NP-her both times.

option.text:
(S-cleared
  (NP-husband (PRP$ her) (NN husband))
  (VP-cleared (VBD cleared)
    (NP-mother
      (NP-visit (DT a) (NN visit))
      (PP-by
        (IN by)
        (NP-mother (PRP$ her) (NN mother))))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head of a noun phrase is the main noun in the phrase (or head of the main child noun phrase).
In particular, it should be NP-visit, not NP-mother.

data.text:
Lexicalize the following parse tree (annotate each non-terminal with the head of the phrase over which it is a constituent):

(S
  (NP (PRP I))
  (VP (MD ca) (RB n't))
  (VP
    (VB help)
    (NP (NNP you))
    (PP
      (IN with)
      (NP (DT this) (NN one)))))
(. .)

option.text:
(S-help
  (NP-I (PRP I))
  (VP-ca (MD ca) (RB n't))
  (VP-help
    (VB help)
    (NP-you (NNP you))
    (PP-with
      (IN with)
      (NP-one (DT this) (NN one)))))
(. .)

(S-I
  (NP-I (PRP I))
  (VP-ca (MD ca) (RB n't))
  (VP-help
    (VB help)
    (NP-you (NNP you))
    (PP-with
      (IN with)
      (NP-one (DT this) (NN one)))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head word of a sentence is the head word of the main verb phrase.
In particular, it should be S-help, not S-I.

option.text:
(S-help
  (NP-I (PRP I))
  (VP-ca (MD ca) (RB n't))
  (VP-you
    (VB help)
    (NP-you (NNP you))
    (PP-with
      (IN with)
      (NP-one (DT this) (NN one)))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head word of a verb phrase is the main verb in the phrase.
In particular, it should be VP-help, not VP-you.

option.text:
(S-help
  (NP-I (PRP I))
  (VP-ca (MD ca) (RB n't))
  (VP-help
    (VB help)
    (NP-you (NNP you))
    (PP-one
      (IN with)
      (NP-one (DT this) (NN one)))))
(. .)
option.explanation:
The head word of a prepositional phrase is the preposition.
In particular, it should be PP-with, not PP-one.

data.text:
Given the following parse trees, 
( (S (NP (DT Every) (NN year))
     (NP (PRP we))
     (VP (VBP seek)
     (NP (NP (NNS companies) (, ,) (NNS organizations) (CC and) (NNS individuals))
         (SBAR (WHNP-1 (-NONE- 0))
           (S (NP (-NONE- *T*-1))
              (VP (TO to)
              (VP (VB sponsor)
